dt.t: right of Congress to {wi}involve{/wi} the nation in war

dt: {bc}to have within or as part of itself {bc}{sx|include||}
{bc}to surround as if with a wrapping {bc}{sx|envelop||}
{bc}to enfold or envelop so as to encumber

pt: {sc}include{/sc} {sc}comprehend{/sc} {sc}embrace{/sc} {sc}involve{/sc} mean to contain within as part of the whole. {sc}include{/sc} suggests the containment of something as a constituent, component, or subordinate part of a larger whole.
{sc}comprehend{/sc} implies that something comes within the scope of a statement or definition.
{sc}embrace{/sc} implies a gathering of separate items within a whole.

pt.t: her faith {it}embraces{/it} both Christian and non-Christian beliefs

pt: {sc}involve{/sc} suggests inclusion by virtue of the nature of the whole, whether by being its natural or inevitable consequence.

pt.t: the new job {it}involves{/it} a lot of detail

et: Middle English {it}envolven, involven{/it} "to cloud (with obscurities), envelop (in darkness, vice), encumber, surround," borrowed from Latin {it}involvere{/it} "to move by rolling, roll back on itself, enclose in a covering, wrap up" (Medieval Latin, "to envelop [in tears, shadows], engage in an affair or occupation, implicate, ensnare"), from {it}in-{/it} {et_link|in-:2|in-:2} + {it}volvere{/it} "to set in a circular course, cause to roll, bring round" {ma}{mat|wallow:2|}{/ma}
shortdef: to occupy (someone, such as oneself) absorbingly; especially : to commit (someone) emotionally
